original_theorem:
A point $\overline{x}$ is a limit
point of a set $S$ if and only if there is a sequence $\{x_n\}$ of points
in $S$ such that $x_n\ne\overline{x}$ for $n\ge 1,$ and
$$
\lim_{n\to\infty}x_n=\overline{x}.
$$
theorem_translation:
```lean4
theorem accumulation_point_iff_sequence_limit
  {α : Type*} [TopologicalSpace α] [FirstCountableTopology α] [T1Space α] (S : Set α) (x_bar : α) :
  x_bar ∈ deriv S ↔ ∃ (x : ℕ → α), (∀ n, x n ∈ S) ∧ (∀ n, x n ≠ x_bar) ∧ Tendsto x atTop (𝓝 x_bar) := by
```

import Mathlib
import Aesop

set_option maxHeartbeats 0
open BigOperators Real Nat Topology Rat Filter
theorem accumulation_point_iff_sequence_limit
  {α : Type*} [TopologicalSpace α] [FirstCountableTopology α] [T1Space α] (S : Set α) (x_bar : α) :
  x_bar ∈ deriv S ↔ ∃ (x : ℕ → α), (∀ n, x n ∈ S) ∧ (∀ n, x n ≠ x_bar) ∧ Tendsto x atTop (𝓝 x_bar) := by sorry

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
• There is a sequence $\{x_n\}_{n\geq 1}$ of points in a set $S$ such that $x_n
e\overline{x}$ for all $n\ge 1,$ and $\lim_{n\to\infty}x_n=\overline{x}$ [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• For each $\epsilon>0$, there exists an integer $N$ such that for all $n\ge N$, we have $0<|x_n-\overline{x}|<\epsilon$ [l1].

proof_steps.natural_language:

• The sequence $\{x_n\}$ is in the set $S$ [tc_1].
• For each $\epsilon>0$, there exists an integer $N$ such that for all $n\ge N$, we have $0<|x_n-\overline{x}|<\epsilon$ [l1].
Therefore, we conclude:
• Every $\epsilon$-neighborhood of $\overline{x}$ (the set of points $y$ with $|y - \overline{x}| < \epsilon$) contains infinitely many points of $S$ [l2].

proof_steps.natural_language:
